item.title: Multiple implementations of same interface - the options
item.description: The challenge Consider a scenario where the requirement is to upload a file to an online provider (AWS S3, Azure Blob or a FTP site in the examples below), where the provider can be easily changed (either dynamically at runtime, or easily with minimal code changes), with the possibility additional providers being added in future. To make use of dependency injection, a generic interface is created, IFileUploader, along with three implementations AWSUploader, AzureUploader and FTPUploader.

item.title: C# String vs string
item.description: What’s the issue? When working with strings in C# one can either use String (uppercase) or string (lowercase) and in both cases the code will compile and execute. Explicitly typed string variables can be done in either of the following ways: string variable = "Always Developing"; String variable = "Always Developing"; Or when invoking string related methods, both of the following examples are valid: string variable = string.Format("Always Developing using {0}", "C#"); String variable = String.
